newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq tones down anti-U.S. rhetoric, defiance.
newsitem.headline: Iraq tones down anti-U.S. rhetoric, defiance.

text.p: Iraqi newspapers on Thursday toned down their defiant rhetoric, a sign that Baghdad may avoid escalating its military confrontation with the United States, at least for the time being.
The newspapers avoided fiery comments or editorials. Their front pages were splashed with pictures of President Saddam Hussein's Wednesday meetings with air defence commanders and chiefs of staff.
In their inside pages they published pictures of "the victims of the criminal American bombing on Wednesday".
The papers shifted focus to world reaction to the U.S. missile strikes, highlighting Russia's condemnation of the attacks, which were prompted by Iraqi military moves in the Kurdish north.

The U.S. fired a total of 44 cruise missiles on Iraq on Tuesday and Wednesday on air defence targets in southern Iraq to minimise Iraqi resistance to its warplanes policing an expanded no-fly zone in southern Iraq.
An Iraqi military communique late on Wednesday spoke of further U.S. strikes on both military and residential targets in and around Baghdad.
Large explosions rocked the Iraqi capital and heavy anti- aircraft fire burst over the city, litting up the night-sky.

The Pentagon denied it had launched any attacks in and around Baghdad. Iraqi officials took Western reporters to a residential area where they saw small craters and an apartment littered with glass and furniture.
Iraq has vowed to defy U.S. and allied air-exclusion zones over its territory. It has urged its pilots and anti-aircraft gunners to shoot down any foreign plane violating its air space.
U.S. warplanes on Wednesday patrolled the new areas which President Bill Clinton added to the former no-fly zone in southern Iraq.
On Wednesday a U.S. warplane fired at an Iraqi radar outside the zone closed to Iraqi aircraft. No other incident has been reported so far.

Iraq's neighbour Turkey showed its readiness to protect its interests in the region. A foreign ministry spokesman said on Wednesday Ankara planned to create a security cordon inside northern Iraq to curb increasing Kurdish separatist activity along the porous border between the two countries.
Turkish troops, backed by air power, could attack Kurdish separatist rebels in northern Iraq at any time, a high-ranking Turksih military official said.

On Thursday Iraq's state-run radio and television were slowly switching to normal programmes after a three-day continuous broadcast of patriotic songs and commentaries urging Iraqi armed forces and people to rise against "criminal (U.S. President) Bill Clinton and his vicious aggression."
The government newspaper al-Jumhouriya in a front-page editorial thanked Russia, France and China for what it described as their pro-Iraq attitudes on Baghdad's latest row with Washington.

The editorial in the official al-Qadissiya called on U.N. Security members not to remain silent on "America's humiliating aggression" on Iraq. So did Babel, the newspaper of Saddam 's eldest son Uday. The official al-Iraq had no comment.
